titlestmt.titleproper: National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 3, Accession 3
A Guide to the National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 3, Accession 3 FA1185

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-07-27 00:29:42 -0400.

did.unittitle: National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 3, Accession 3

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: National Committee on United States-China Relations, Inc.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The National Committee on United States-China Relations donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated March 27, 2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Committee on United States – China Relations (NCUSCR) was established in 1966 as a nonprofit educational organization with a mission to encourage mutual understanding and dialogue between citizens of the United States and China.

The National Committee came into being through the cooperative efforts of scholars and civic, religious, and business leaders who, at a time of mutual hostility between the two countries, sought to stimulate public discussion about China and the United States' relations with it by sponsoring conferences, seminars, publications, and other education and outreach programs. In 1972, the National Committee sponsored the Chinese table tennis team's historic U. S. visit. This round of "Ping Pong Diplomacy," which followed closely on Richard Nixon's visit to China in February 1972, helped pave the way for later exchanges and, eventually, for the normalization of relations with China in 1979. Building on these cultural exchanges, the National Committee came to be a primary organizer of professional and policy exchanges between the two countries (and including Hong Kong and Taiwan), in the areas of foreign affairs and international relations, economic development, governance and legal affairs, education, mass media, environmental and global issues, etc. As its role in exchanges became more prominent, the National Committee turned over some of its educational programs to the Asia Society in the late 1970s, but it continues its educational role through public education events and ongoing outreach.
Funding for the National Committee comes from the United States government (especially the Department of State), corporations, and foundations, as well as from its individual membership.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the National Committee on United States – China Relations are divided into ten record groups, which reflect the order in which the records were received (but which are otherwise an artificial distinction). The records are sorted intellectually into series, which carry over through all record groups, but they have received little or no physical rearrangement. RG 3 of the NCUSCR records contains records from seven series: 1 – Events; 2 – Exchanges - General; 3 - Exchanges to China; 4 – Exchanges from China; 6 – Publications and Reports; 8 - Programs, Projects, and Proposals; and 9 – Ping Pong Diplomacy.

The RG 3 accession also includes a few boxes of audiovisual materials, which, pending further processing, have not been included in the FA1185 finding aid. They will be arranged and described with other, related audiovisual materials in a subsequent record group and finding aid.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Special formats separated from the body of the collection are stored in the following containers: Box 34: FA1185:001 - FA1185:026; Box OS 1: FA1185:027, FA1185:029

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RG 3 of the NCUSCR records documents the National Committee's ongoing work on behalf of cross-cultural orientation and understanding through its Scholar and Teachers Orientation Programs, Fulbright-Hays Summer Seminars, Student Leaders Exchange, and Young Leaders Forums in particular. Materials in the Exchanges from China series document the visits of athletic teams and other delegations from China in 1976–1978 and 1980. Also in the Programs, Projects, and Proposals series are records relating to the National Committee's "China Town Hall: Local Connections, National Reflections" webcasts and conversations on China, especially in 2007–2008; and files relating to the surveys it conducted for the Ford Foundation and the MacArthur Foundation, 2002–2007, on the topic of U. S. – China / International Relations and Security Issues. The Publications series includes National Committee brochures from 1973 – 2014, and its China Policy Series pamphlets from 1989-2007.

The RG 3 accession includes a few boxes of audiovisual materials that have not been included in this finding aid. The recordings – including the 2003 U. S. Foreign Policy Colloquium; China Conversations programs; and the Ping Pong matches in 1972 – pending processing, will be arranged and described with other, related audiovisual materials in a subsequent record group and finding aid.

did.unittitle: Events
Scholar Orientation Program Reunion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beijing. Reunion held on occasion of the fourteenth year of the program. Includes background and planning correspondence.

did.unittitle: Exchanges - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges - General series in RG 3 contains records of the National Committee's Young Leaders Forum, from 2001 to 2013, and of its Teachers Orientation Program, from 1997 to 2004.

Established in 2002 in partnership with the Chinese People's Institute of Foreign Affairs and still ongoing, the annual Young Leaders Forum (YLF) brings together a select group of American and Chinese young professionals for a four- or five-day retreat at sites that alternate between the U. S. and China. Organized around a theme, meetings seek to develop mutual understanding and personal connections and dialogue among fellows, who represent not only two countries and cultures, but also a diverse range of professional backgrounds and interests.

Starting in 1997, the Teachers Orientation Program organized a separate two-week study tour on American History and Culture for Chinese participants in the Teachers Exchange Program, established in 1996. Modeled on the Scholar Orientation Program (SOP) (see the Programs, Projects, and Proposals series), Teachers Orientation Program trips were numbered in a consecutive series with their SOP counterparts. RG 3 documents the TOP program from 1997 – 2004 (SOP numbers 76 – 77, 80, 83, and 85 – 87). Additional materials concerning Teachers Orientation programs and records of study tours from 2006 – 2009 are found in RG 1 (FA772).

did.unittitle: Exchanges to China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges to China series in RG 3 contains records and briefing materials for participants in the Student Leaders Exchange, 2004 – 2007, and 2013. Begun in 2004, the Student Leaders Exchange program sponsored twelve U. S. high-school students (Presidential Scholars) annually on a two-week study trip to China (reciprocal visits from China began in 2007). The series also includes Curriculum Projects created by participants in Fulbright-Hays Seminars Abroad, for 1991, 1994-1998, and 2002. One final file relates to the State Education Leaders Delegation, which traveled to China in 1977.

did.unittitle: Exchanges from China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges from China series contains records of delegations from 1976 – 1978 and 1980, documenting, notably, the visits of several sports teams (Volleyball, Soccer, Basketball, and Diving), and the visit of a high-level delegation from the Chinese People's Institute of Foreign Affairs. Other files concern visits from the Ministry of Culture, the Chinese International Travel Bureau (Luxingshe), an Urban Transportation delegation, and other educational and cultural delegations.

Publications and Reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Publications and Reports series in RG 3 contains the National Committee's China Policy Series pamphlets, numbers 1 – 23 (1989 – 2007), as well as various publications and brochures from National Committee programs and events, ranging in date from 1971 to 2014.

did.unittitle: Programs, Projects, and Proposals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Programs, Projects, and Proposals series in RG 3 contains records relating especially to the China Town Hall program and the Scholar Orientation Program, and to surveys the National Committee conducted for the Ford Foundation and the MacArthur Foundation.

Launched in 2007, the China Town Hall program seeks to foster a national conversation on China and issues pertaining to U. S. – China relations. The annual program features a national webcast address by a prominent speaker, which is paired with local speaker and discussion programs organized at venues around the country. Materials in RG 3 pertain mainly to planning and organization for the 2007 and 2008 programs.

The Scholar Orientation Program (SOP), which ran from 1980 to 2002, sought to ensure that Chinese scholars and students pursing advanced studies in the U.S. would return to China with a fuller understanding and appreciation of U.S. history, culture, and government. Grouping participants by common interests (such as Law, Economics, or American Studies), the National Committee ran two-week study tours that usually included visits to Williamsburg or Boston, Washington, DC, Philadelphia, and New York. Participants visited historic sites and cultural institutions, attended lectures, and met with officials and professional colleagues; visits also usually included a homestay in the Washington, DC, area with National Committee members and friends. The National Committee organized several SOP trips a year, which it numbered consecutively. The files, which tend to be slim, contain name lists, itineraries, some host-family information, and occasional reports or clippings; later files also include travel and programming information. For Teachers Orientation Programs, which were numbered in sequence with the other SOP delegations, see the Exchanges – General series.

This segment of the Programs, Projects, and Proposals series also includes records of a survey the National Committee conducted for the Ford Foundation in 2000 on U. S. organizations with programs relating to U.S. – China Relations and Security Issues. The National Committee submitted its internal report to the foundation in January 2003 and updated it in 2005, again at Ford's behest. This second internal report, Survey of Programs on United States – China Relations and Security Issues, submitted in January 2006, formed the basis for the public report of the same title published in the China Policy Series (no. 23) in March 2007. The files include copies of both reports, survey responses, plus a small amount of correspondence. This series also includes one file on the National Committee's Fall 2006 survey for the MacArthur Foundation concerning Chinese Programs on International Relations and Asian Security Issues.

Finally, this series also contains a set of files labeled "Background Readings," which consists of copies of articles and notes, dated 1972 – 2003, relating especially to religion in China. These readings files probably belonged to Jason Kindopp, a resident scholar at the NCUSCR who was studying unofficial religious groups in China.

Survey of Programs on United States-China Relations and Security Issues: Report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On behalf of the Ford Foundation, the National Committee surveyed American organizations concerning their programs relating to U. S. - China relations and security issues. This report was submitted to the Ford Foundation for its internal use. Two copies of report in file.

did.unittitle: Survey of Programs on United States-China Relations and Security Issues: Report and Appendices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Report dated 2006, marked "Second Ford Report," was an internal report to the Ford Foundation, updated from 2003 report. The report was subsequently published in March 2007 in the NCUSCR's China Policy Series, no. 23.

did.unittitle: Survey of Programs on United States-China Relations and Security Issues: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 2005 survey response for Insitute for Foreign Policy Analysis.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation Survey Responses: General (A-Z)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Survey of Programs on International Relations and Security Issues involving the United States, China, and the Asia-Pacific Region - Questionnaire. Responses for Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies; John M. Olin Institute for Strategic Studies; Duke University, Center for International Studies; Stanford University, Center for International Security and Cooperation; University of Colorado, Boulder, Sino-American Security Dialogue; U. S. Naval War College; U. S. Military Academy, West Point; Henry L Stimson Center; Heritage Foundation.
